intro: Acalypha strobilifera, commonly known as the coral tree, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its striking, red or orange inflorescences that resemble clusters of coral, hence its common name. The plant belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is known for its ornamental value in gardens. Its leaves are typically heart-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while the stems are often woody and branching. Acalypha strobilifera thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, preferring well-drained soil and full sunlight.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acalypha strobilifera is primarily native to tropical and subtropical regions of Southeast Asia, including countries such as Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. It thrives in humid, lowland areas with rich soil and ample sunlight. This plant is commonly found in forest understories and along riverbanks. It is also present in parts of the Philippines and New Guinea. Due to its ornamental value, it has been introduced to other tropical regions around the world.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha strobilifera was mainly introduced to coastal and sandy areas for its ornamental value and ability to stabilize dunes. It is commonly found in regions with warm, humid climates and well-drained soils. The plant is often used in restoration projects due to its rapid growth and hardiness. However, it can become invasive in some environments if not managed properly. Its introduction has raised concerns about its impact on native ecosystems in certain areas.
